Scheme 1 Products obtained from the reaction of fructose with different alcohols. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Selective synthesis of HMF and LA from fructose. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 Reaction of fructose catalyzed by different oxo-rhenium complexes: 1. HReO4; 2. [ReOCl3(SMe2)(OPPh3)]; 3. ReOCl3(PPh3)2; 4. ReIO2(PPh3)2; 5. MTO; 6. NaReO4. Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol), catalyst (10 mol%), EtOH (5 mL), 160 °C, 16 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Effect of catalyst HReO4 amount on the conversion of fructose into EL. Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol), EtOH (5 mL), 160 °C, 16 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of reaction temperature on the conversion of fructose into EL. Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol), HReO4 (10 mol%), EtOH (5 mL), 16 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Monitoring of fructose conversion. Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol), HReO4 (10 mol%), EtOH (5 mL), 160 °C. Yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Conversion of several carbohydrates into EL. Reaction conditions: Carbohydrate (1 mmol of hexose), HReO4 (10 mol%), EtOH (5 mL), 160 °C, 16 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1HNMR spectroscopy. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Monitoring of EL formation from different carbohydrates. Reaction conditions: Carbohydrate (1 mmol of hexose), HReO4 (10 mol%), EtOH (5 mL), 160 °C. Yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Use of catalyst HReO4 in multiple cycles. Reaction conditions: Fructose (0.5 mmol in each cycle); HReO4 (10 mol%), EtOH (5 mL), 160 °C, 16 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Synthesis of EL in gram scale. Reaction conditions: HReO4 (10 mol%), EtOH 160 °C, 16 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Monitoring of fructose conversion at different temperatures (120–150 °C) and different reaction times (30 min-2 h). Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol); HReO4 (10 mol%); EtOH (5 mL). Yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Effect of different co-solvents on the conversion of fructose. Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol); HReO4 (10 mol%), VTotal(5 mL), 140 °C, 1 h. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Synthesis of EMF from other carbohydrates. Reaction conditions: Carbohydrate (1 mmol of hexose), HReO4 (10 mol%), THF/EtOH = 3:7 (VTotal = 5 mL), 1 h, 140 °C. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Effect of solvent in the reaction of fructose. Reaction conditions: Fructose (1 mmol); HReO4 (10 mol%), VSolvent = 5 mL, 1 h, 140 °C. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 Synthesis of HMF from different carbohydrates. Reactions conditions: Carbohydrate (1 mmol of hexose), HReO4 (10 mol%), VDMSO = 5 mL, 1 h, 140 °C. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 13 Fig. 14 Monitoring of HMF yield obtained from sucrose and glucose. Reaction conditions: Carbohydrate (1 mmol of hexose), HReO4 (10 mol%), DMSO (5 mL), 140 °C. Yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 14 Fig. 15 Synthesis of LA from different carbohydrates. Reaction conditions: Carbohydrate (1 mmol of hexose), HReO4 (10 mol%), VDMSO = 5 mL, 1 h, 140 °C. Conversions and yields determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. Fig. 15 Table 1 Conversion of fructose catalyzed by different acids. Table 1 Entry Catalyst Catalyst amount (%) Temp.(ºC) Conversion (%) HMF (%) EMF (%) EL (%) AL (%) 1 H2SO4 10 100 92 0 33 10 ― 2 HCl 10 100 100 9 32 10 ― 3 DMSO/H2SO4 10 100 98 0 42 12 ― 4 DMSO/H2SO4 10 140 ― 0 55 26 ― 5 DMSO/H2SO4 10 160 ― 0 30 30 60 6 DMSO/HCl 10 100 99 10 36 10 ― 7 DMSO/HI 10 100 99 2 9 3 ― 8 DMSO/CH3SO3H 10 100 99 0 37 13 ― 9 HReO4/DMSO 10 140 100 100 ― ― ― 10 HReO4/dioxane 10 140 100 ― ― ― 100 11 HReO4/EtOH 10 160 100 ― ― 80 ― 12 HReO4/EtOH/THF 10 140 90 ― 73 ― ― HReO4 as highly efficient and selective catalyst for the conversion of carbohydrates into value added chemicals Joana R. Bernardo M. Conceição Oliveira Ana C. Fernandes ⁎ Centro de Química Estrutural, Instituto Superior Técnico, Universidade de Lisboa, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal Centro de Química Estrutural Instituto Superior Técnico Universidade de Lisboa Av. Rovisco Pais Lisboa 1049-001 Portugal ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This work describes the first catalyst (HReO4) that promotes the efficient and selective conversion of several carbohydrates into four compounds, ethyl levulinate (EL), 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and levulinic acid (LA), through a one-pot reaction strategy adjusting the reaction conditions. The reaction of fructose in ethanol at 160 °C gave EL in 80% yield after 16 h and in a mixture of ethanol/THF at 140 °C produced EMF in 73% yield after 1 h. HMF and LA can also be obtained selectively with 100% yield from fructose at 140 °C after 1 h, in DMSO or 1,4-dioxane, respectively. EL, HMF, LA and EMF were also produced in moderate to good yields from other carbohydrates such as inulin and sucrose. The catalyst HReO4 can be used in gram scale for the production of EL, EMF, HMF and LA with good yields and in at least 8 catalytic cycles on the conversion of fructose into EL with no significant reduction in its activity. Keywords Oxo-rhenium complexes Ethyl levulinate 5-Ethoxymethylfurfural 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Levulinic acid 1 Introduction Due to environmental concerns, diminishing fossil resources and the high price of petrochemicals, it is urgent to develop and use renewable resources. Biomass is the most attractive alternative and different biomass carbohydrate-derived chemicals including alkyl levulinate, 5-alkoxymethylfurfural ethers, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and levulinic acid have been considered versatile platform compounds for the preparation of a diversity of fine chemicals, biofuels and biological compounds. Ethyl levulinate (EL) has been widely used as an additive for gasoline and diesel due to the similar properties with the biodiesel fatty acid methyl esters and also as solvent and plasticizer in food industry [1,2]. 5-Ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) has attracted much attention as a potential biofuel alternative because of its high energy density of 30.3 MJ L−1, close to that of diesel (33.6 MJ L−1), gasoline (31.1 MJ L−1) and ethanol (23.5 MJ L−1), and also due to the high oxidation stability of EMF that can lead to the reduction of emission of soot, NOx and SOx [3]. Usually, the synthesis of EL or EMF involves the esterification of a biomass-derived substrate catalyzed by an acid catalyst [4]. For example, Tominaga group reported the direct conversion of cellulose into alkyl levulinates using mixed-acid systems, containing Lewis and Brønsted acids [5]. Lin and Liu studied the synthesis of EL from glucose employing SO4 2−/ZrO2 − based solid acid catalysts [6,7]. The production of EMF and EL catalyzed by sulfonic acid-functionalized ionic liquids [8] SBA-15 [9] and zeolites was investigated by Riisager group [10]. Different heteropolyacids were also employed for the conversion of biomass into biofuels. For example, EMF was obtained with 65% yield in the presence of H3PW12O40 under microwave heating [11], and Wang and Chen [12] reported the transformation of HMF into EMF (55%) and EL (11%) catalyzed by MOFs-based heteropolyacid materials. HMF, a sustainable and versatile precursor for petrochemical industry and biofuel chemistry, is produced mainly by dehydration of biomass-based carbohydrates catalyzed by mineral acids [13], organic acids [14], acidic resins [15–17], oxides [18], phosphates [19] and zeolites [20]. More recently, acidic ionic liquids (ILs) have also been employed as catalysts or as solvents for the synthesis of HMF [21,22]. Another important bioderived platform chemical, levulinic acid (LA), has been employed as plasticizer, food flavoring agent, solvent, resin intermediate and building block [23–25]. Usually, the synthesis of LA involves the reaction of carbohydrates with aqueous mineral acid (H2SO4 and HCl) at high temperature (100–250 °C), affording LA with low yields (∼40%). Using continuous flow conditions at higher temperatures and pressures, LA yield may be improved to 60–70% [26]. However, a major drawback in this process is the tedious work-up during the separation stages. Heterogeneous catalysts are very selective and do not present corrosion problems, but, until now, the use of heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of LA is still rare in comparison to homogeneous catalysts [27]. Due to the high importance of the conversion of carbohydrates into biofuels and value added chemicals, the research for efficient catalysts is a key target in organic chemistry and also in the chemical industry. In the last years, oxo-rhenium complexes have been applied in the deoxygenation of many organic compounds [28] such as sulfoxides [29–35], epoxides [36–42], aromatic nitro compounds [43], N-oxides [44], alcohols [45–48] and carbonyl compounds [49,50]. The synthesis of EL, EMF, and LA has never been studied using oxo-rhenium complexes as catalysts. In this work, we report the first methodology for the direct and selective conversion of carbohydrates into potential fuels and value added chemicals such as EL, EMF, HMF and LA catalyzed by oxo-rhenium complexes. 2 Methods 2.1 General information All the reactions were carried out under air atmosphere, without using any dry solvent. Carbohydrates and HReO4 (75–80 wt.% in H2O), MTO, NaReO4 were obtained from commercial suppliers and were used without further purification. ReIO2(PPh3)2 [51], ReOCl3(PPh3)2 [52] and [ReOCl3(SMe2)(OPPh3)] [53] were prepared according to literature procedures. Flash chromatography was performed on MN Kieselgel 60 M 230–400 mesh. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance II+ 400 MHz and 300 MHz spectrometers. Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million (ppm) downfield from an internal standard. 2.2 Synthesis of EL 2.2.1 General procedure for the conversion of carbohydrates into EL To a Schlenk flask equipped with a J. Young tap containing a solution of carbohydrate (0.180 g, 1.0 mmol of hexose) in ethanol (5 mL) was added HReO4 (0.025 g, 10 mol%). The reaction mixture was stirred in a closed Schlenk at 160 °C during 16 h. The yields of the products were determined by spectroscopy 1H NMR using mesitylene as internal standard. 2.2.2 Use of catalyst HReO4 in several cycles To a Schlenk flask equipped with a J. Young tap containing a solution of fructose (0.09 g, 0.5 mmol) in ethanol (5 mL) was added HReO4 (0.0126 g, 10 mol%). The reaction mixture was stirred in a closed Schlenk at 160 °C during 16 h. The reaction mixture was cooled and the yield was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using mesytilene (0.5 mmol) as internal standard. In the next catalytic cycles, fructose (0.5 mmol) and mesytilene (0.5 mmol) were added to the reaction mixture and stirred for 16 h at 160 °C. The reaction mixture was cooled and the yields were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. 2.2.3 Synthesis of EL in gram scale To a Schlenk flask equipped with a J. Young tap containing a solution of fructose (1.80 g, 10 mmol) in ethanol (50 mL) was added HReO4 (0.25 g, 10 mol%). The reaction mixture was stirred in a closed Schlenk at 160 °C during 16 h. The yields were determined by spectroscopy 1H NMR using mesitylene as internal standard. 2.3 General procedure for the conversion of carbohydrates into EMF To a Schlenk flask equipped with a J. Young tap containing a solution of carbohydrate (0.180 g, 1.0 mmol of hexose) in a mixture ethanol/THF (7/3) (Vtotal = 5 mL) was added HReO4 (0.025 g, 10 mol%). The reaction mixture was stirred in a closed Schlenk at 140 °C during 1 h. The yields were determined by spectroscopy 1H NMR using mesitylene as internal standard. 2.4 General procedure for the conversion of carbohydrates into HMF To a Schlenk flask equipped with a J. Young tap containing a solution of carbohydrate (0.180 g, 1.0 mmol of hexose) in DMSO (5 mL) was added HReO4 (0.025 g, 10 mol%). The reaction mixture was stirred in a closed Schlenk at 140 °C during 1 h. The yields were determined by spectroscopy 1H NMR using mesitylene as internal standard. 2.5 General procedure for the conversion of carbohydrates into LA To a Schlenk flask equipped with a J. Young tap containing a solution of carbohydrate (0.180 g, 1.0 mmol of hexose) in 1,4-dioxane (5 mL) was added HReO4 (0.025 g, 10 mol%). The reaction mixture was stirred in a closed Schlenk at 140 °C during 1 h. The yields were determined by spectroscopy 1H NMR using mesitylene as internal standard. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of alkyl levulinates Initially, we optimized the conversion of carbohydrates into ethyl levulinate using different reaction conditions. 3.1.1 Effect of the catalyst The conversion of fructose was studied using 10 mol% of different oxo-rhenium complexes as catalysts (Fig. 1 ). The best result was obtained in the presence of the Re(VII) complex HReO4 in ethanol at 160 °C, producing selectively EL with 80% yield after 16 h. The reactions catalyzed by [ReOCl3(OPPh3)(SMe2)] and MTO also gave selectively EL with 53% and 16% yields, respectively. In the presence of ReOCl3(PPh3)2, EL was afforded in 50% yield along with 12% yield of EMF. A mixture of EL (44%), EMF (5%) and HMF (8%) was obtained in the reaction catalyzed by the oxo-complex ReIO2(PPh3)2. Among the Re(V) complexes, the electronic properties of the halide ligands Cl and I can influence the activity of the catalysts, leading to a slight higher activity for the catalyst containing the Cl ligand. Finally, the weak chelate character of the ligands SMe2 and OPPh3 also enhances the catalytic activity of [ReOCl3(SMe2)(OPPh3)]. The conversion of fructose using NaReO4 as catalyst afforded only 11% of EL and 22% of EMF, confirming the importance of the presence of the Brønsted acid. Finally, no reaction was observed in the absence of catalyst. 3.1.2 Effect of catalyst amount The effect of catalyst (HReO4) amount on the conversion of fructose into EL is presented in Fig. 2 . The reaction performed with 5 mol% of HReO4 afforded a mixture of EL and EMF in 66% and 17% yields, respectively. The best result was obtained with 10 mol%, giving selectively EL with 80% yield. Using 20 mol% of HReO4, EL was produced selectively, but with slight lower yield (75%), observing the formation of insoluble humins. 3.1.3 Effect of reaction temperature The reaction of fructose catalyzed by HReO4 in ethanol was carried out at different temperatures from 80 to 180 °C. As evidenced by Fig. 3 , a significant effect of the reaction temperature on the products distribution was observed. Higher temperatures accelerated the rate of fructose conversion into EL. At low temperature (80 °C), a mixture of EMF (42%) and EL (16%) was formed. The reactions carried out between 100–140 °C also led to the formation of a mixture of EMF and EL, but an increase in the reaction temperature improves EL yield, as a result of decreasing of EMF. At 160 °C, EL was produced selectively with 80% yield. Finally, higher temperature (180 °C) led to a slight decrease of EL yield, probably due to the formation of humins. 3.1.4 The effect of reaction time on the conversion of fructose A typical time profile for fructose conversion catalyzed by HReO4 is shown in Fig. 4 . In the first 0.5 h, the maximum EMF yield (65%) was achieved along with a small amount of EL (10%). Then, EMF yield began to drop, while EL yield continued to rise to a maximum value (80%) after 16 h. 3.1.5 Synthesis of different alkyl levulinates Due to high chemical importance of alkyl levulinates, the conversion of fructose into different alkyl levulinates was also investigated with methanol and isopropanol under the same reaction conditions described before for the synthesis of ethyl levulinate (10 mol% of HReO4, 160 °C, 16 h). The reaction of fructose with methanol gave methyl levulinate (ML) with 76% yield (Scheme 1 ). In contrast, the reaction of fructose with isopropanol produced a mixture of alkyl levulinate (IL) (22%), alkoxymethylfurfural (IMF) (20%) and hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) (4%) derivatives in low yields. This result demonstrated that isopropanol is not a good solvent for the selective conversion of fructose into the corresponding alkyl levulinate, leading also to the formation of furanosidic derivatives. 3.1.6 Synthesis of EL from different carbohydrates In order to test the scope and limitations of our catalytic system, the synthesis of EL from other carbohydrates was also explored. Under the same reaction conditions used for the conversion of fructose into EL (10 mol% HReO4, ethanol 160 °C, 16 h), this compound was obtained from inulin, sucrose and glucose with 65%, 52% and 27% yields, respectively and no formation of HMF or EMF was observed (Fig. 5 ). These results also demonstrate that HReO4 has also the ability to hydrolyze the glycosidic bonds of di- and polysaccharides to the corresponding monomers (fructose and glucose). The EL yield obtained from inulin is higher than the value obtained for sucrose because one molecule of inulin contains just one molecule of glucose and 1–59 molecules of fructose while one molecule of sucrose contains one molecule of glucose and only one molecule of fructose. To improve the EL yield obtained from inulin, sucrose and glucose, the formation of EL synthesized from these carbohydrates was monitored during 72 h. Fig. 6 shows that the reaction of glucose is slow, but after 72 h it is possible to obtain EL with 80% yield. In the reaction of sucrose was initially observed a rapid conversion of this disaccharide into EL, corresponding to about half of EL yield obtained in the reaction of fructose, which should result only from fructose conversion, after the sucrose hydrolysis. Thereafter, an increase of EL yield was observed as result of glucose conversion to give the maximum EL yield (80%). 3.1.7 Use of catalyst HReO4 in multiple cycles The possibility of using the catalyst HReO4 in multiple cycles was investigated on the conversion of fructose into EL in ethanol at 160 °C by successive additions of fructose to the reaction mixture, without separating the catalyst at the end of each cycle (Fig. 7 ). The yield obtained for each catalytic cycle was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using mesitylene as internal standard. The obtained results showed that the catalyst can be used in at least 8 cycles with good activity. 3.1.8 Synthesis of EL in gram scale The catalytic activity of HReO4 on the conversion of fructose was also tested in gram scale (Fig. 8 ). The reactions were performed using 10 and 20 mmol of fructose at 160 °C during 16 h, affording EL in 80% and 75% yield, respectively. These results are similar to the yield obtained from 1 mmol of fructose, showing that this catalyst can be used in gram scale. 3.1.9 Conversion of fructose in EL monitoring by LC-ESI-MS/MS technique As described in the literature [54], HMF and EMF are the most significant intermediate species in EL formation. The kinetic study performed for the conversion of fructose into EL catalyzed by HReO4 in ethanol at 160 °C (Fig. 4) demonstrated that EMF is an intermediate in the synthesis of EL, observing the decrease in its yield while increasing EL yield. However, the formation of HMF or other intermediates was not detected by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The conversion of fructose into EL, under the same reaction conditions, was also monitored by LC-ESI-MS/MS technique. After 5 min of reaction, traces of fructose were detected and after 15 min all the fructose had been consumed. The peaks corresponding to the formation of the intermediates HMF (Figure S1, Sup. Inf.), EMF (Figure S2, Sup. Inf.) and traces of HMF diethyl acetal (HMFda) were also observed by LC-ESI-MS/MS after 5 and 15 min, which disappeared during the reaction. The LC-ESI-MS/MS technique also detected the peak corresponding to the formation of EL, even after 5 min, which increased over the reaction (Figure S3, Sup. Inf.). These results suggested that the conversion of fructose into EL involves the dehydration of fructose into HMF, followed by etherification of HMF giving EMF, and re-hydration of EMF producing EL and ethyl formate. The conversion of glucose into EL catalyzed by HReO4 was also monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy and LC-ESI-MS/MS techniques. Although, the glucose was converted into EL with 80% yield after 72 h (Fig. 6), the formation of HMF or EMF from glucose was never observed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. In acid medium, glucose can react with ethanol producing ethyl glucopyranoside [55,56]. The formation of this derivative as intermediate on the glucose conversion into EL was also detected by LC-ESI-MS/MS technique, along with the product EL, even after 24 h. Since the formation of HMF and EMF was not detected by 1H NMR and LC-ESI-MS/MS techniques, we believe that on the conversion of glucose into EL catalyzed by HReO4, ethyl glucopyranoside derivative should be transformed into other species that give rise to EL, unlike to other methods using Brønsted acids as catalysts, in which this derivative remains unchanged. 3.2 Synthesis of 5-alkoxymethylfurfural ethers The selective conversion of carbohydrates into 5-alkoxymethylfurfural ethers was also studied in this work using different temperatures, reaction times and solvents. 3.2.1 Effect of reaction temperature As described before, the reaction of fructose in ethanol at 160 °C gave EMF with 65% yield, along with 10% yield of EL, after 30 min (Fig. 4). In order to optimize the selective synthesis of EMF, we also studied the effect of the temperature on the synthesis of EMF. The conversion of fructose was performed at 120, 130, 140 and 150 °C and the reactions were monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy after 30 min, 1 h, 1 h 30 min and 2 h (Fig. 9 ). At 120 °C, EMF yield decreased and the maximum EMF yield (56%) was observed only after 2 h. However, the reaction was not selective, producing also 12% of EL. EMF was selectively obtained with 60% yield after 1 h at 130 °C, but longer reaction times led to the decrease of EMF yield and to the formation of EL. At 140 °C, EMF was selectively obtained with the best yield (63%) after 1 h. Finally, at 150 °C, the formation of EMF was not selective. These results revealed that the best EMF yield was obtained at 140 °C after 1 h. 3.2.2 The effect of different co-solvents As described in the literature [57], the addition of a co-solvent to ethanol, such as THF, on the conversion of fructose can increases the EMF yield. Based on this result, the reaction of fructose catalyzed by HReO4 in ethanol was carried out using different organic co-solvents including THF, DMSO, n-hexane, toluene and 1,4-dioxane (Fig. 10 ). As reported before, the conversion of fructose performed in ethanol gave EMF in 63% yield at 140 °C after 1 h (Fig. 9). The addition of THF to ethanol (3:7, Vtotal = 5 mL) increased EMF yield to 73%. However, higher volumes of THF, for example, ethanol/THF (1:1) decreased the EMF yield (45%). The use of THF as co-solvent led to an increase in EMF yield, possibly because THF provides a more hydrophobic medium than ethanol, enabling the separation of EMF and also the reduction of humins formation. The addition of DMSO, a more polar co-solvent, decreased the rate of HMF etherification, producing a mixture of HMF (39%) and EMF (32%), while the use of apolar co-solvents, such as n-hexane and toluene, afforded a mixture of EL and EMF. Thus, it can be concluded that the use of a strongly apolar co-solvent accelerates the reaction rate, leading to the formation of large quantities of EL, even after 1 h of reaction. Finally, the conversion of fructose in ethanol using 1,4-dioxane as co-solvent gave a mixture of EMF (43%), EL (20%) and LA (25%). Based on these results, the mixture ethanol/THF (7:3) was chosen as the best solvent for the conversion of fructose into EMF. 3.2.3 Synthesis of EMF from other carbohydrates After optimizing the reaction conditions to synthesize EMF from fructose, the preparation of EMF from other carbohydrates such as inulin and sucrose was also investigated (Fig. 11 ). EMF was formed in 51% yield from inulin, along with 18% yield of EL, and in 36% yield from sucrose. 3.2.4 Synthesis of EMF in gram scale The applicability of HReO4 as catalyst for the synthesis of EMF in gram scale was also explored. The reaction of 10 mmol (1.8 g) of fructose was carried out in ethanol using 10 mol% of HReO4 at 140 °C during 1 h, affording EMF in 63% yield along with 13% yield of EL. 3.3 Synthesis of HMF In this work was also investigated the selective conversion of carbohydrates into HMF catalyzed by HReO4 using different reaction conditions. 3.3.1 Effect of solvent As described before, the conversion of fructose using DMSO as co-solvent in ethanol gave a mixture of HMF (39%) and EMF (32%) (Fig. 10). Based on this result, we performed the reaction of fructose catalyzed by 10 mol% of HReO4 in DMSO at 140 °C. After 1 h, all fructose was converted, producing HMF with 100% yield (Fig. 12 ). This reaction was also conducted in DMF and MeCN affording HMF with 50% and 25% yields, respectively. Using THF as solvent, the reaction was not selective, giving HMF in 30% yield and levulinic acid (LA) in 28% yield. In toluene, the HMF yield was residual, due to the formation of humins, probably related to the low solubility of fructose in this solvent. These results show that DMSO is the best solvent, producing HMF with 100% yield after 1 h at 140 °C. This result is similar to others described in the literature which reports that the use of polar organic solvent, such as DMSO, can suppress the formation of condensation products and diminish the rehydration of HMF. Finally, we also carried out the reaction of fructose in 1,4-dioxane catalyzed by HReO4 at 140 °C during 1 h and surprisingly LA was obtained with 100% yield, probably as result of the rehydration of HMF (Fig. 12). The solvent effect study showed that the choice of solvent is crucial for the nature of the product obtained in the reaction of fructose catalyzed by HReO4. Thus, it is possible to conclude that DMSO led to the selective formation of HMF with 100% yield and 1,4-dioxane allowed the selective synthesis of LA also in 100% yield (Scheme 2 ). 3.3.2 Synthesis of HMF from different carbohydrates The excellent HMF yield obtained from fructose using DMSO as solvent encouraged us to explore the synthesis of HMF from other carbohydrates (Fig. 13 ). HMF was formed with 78% and 66% yields from inulin and sucrose, respectively. In contrast, only 20% yield of HMF was obtained from glucose. To optimize the HMF yield obtained from sucrose and glucose, these reactions were monitored during 4 h and 8 h, respectively (Fig. 14 ). The analysis of Fig. 14 shows that the maximum HMF yield was obtained after 2 h from sucrose (79%) and after 6 h from glucose (64%). Longer reaction times decreased the HMF yield, probably due to the formation of humins. 3.3.3 Synthesis of LA from different carbohydrates The synthesis of LA from different carbohydrates was explored using 10 mol% of HReO4 in 1,4-dioxane at 140 °C during 1 h (Fig. 15 ). LA was obtained with 97% and 85% yields from inulin and sucrose, respectively. In contrast, the reaction of glucose only gave 50% yield of LA after 1 h, but after 3 h this yield increased to 89%. 3.3.4 Synthesis of HMF and LA in gram scale The catalytic activity of HReO4 was also evaluated in the synthesis of HMF and LA in gram scale. From the reaction of fructose (10 mmol) in DMSO at 140 °C, HMF was obtained in 78% yield after 1 h. Similarly, the reaction of fructose (10 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane at 140 °C gave LA with 75% yield after 1 h, along with traces of HMF. These yields are lower than the HMF yield (100%) and LA yield (100%) obtained from 1 mmol of fructose. In Table 1 are summarized the results reported in the literature using conventional acid as catalysts such as H2SO4, HCl, HI or CH3SO3H [58] and also the results reported in this work using HReO4, confirming the high efficiency and selectivity of this catalyst for the synthesis of EL, EMF, HMF and LA. 4 Conclusions This work describes the highly efficient and selective conversion of carbohydrates into EL, EMF, HMF and LA catalyzed by HReO4. This is the first catalyst that allows the selective conversion of different carbohydrates into four important compounds (fuels and added value chemicals) in good to excellent yields, only by changing the reaction parameters. This method has also the advantages of the catalyst HReO4 can be used in gram scale for the production of EL, EMF, HMF and LA with good yields and in at least 8 catalytic cycles for the conversion of fructose into EL, with no significant reduction in its activity. Among the oxo-rhenium complexes reported in the literature, HReO4 has relative low cost, is commercially available and air stable. These results extend the scope of the use of oxo-rhenium complexes as efficient catalysts for the synthesis of fuels and value added chemicals from renewable resource. Acknowledgements Authors thank the project UID/QUI/00100/2013 and the Portuguese NMR Network (IST-UTL Center) for providing access to the NMR facilities. J. R. B. thanks FCT for grant (SFRH/BD/90659/2012) and ACF (IF/00849/2012) acknowledges FCT for the “Investigador FCT” Program. coredata.dc:description: This work describes the first catalyst (HReO4) that promotes the efficient and selective conversion of several carbohydrates into four compounds, ethyl levulinate (EL), 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF), 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) and levulinic acid (LA), through a one-pot reaction strategy adjusting the reaction conditions. The reaction of fructose in ethanol at 160 °C gave EL in 80% yield after 16 h and in a mixture of ethanol/THF at 140 °C produced EMF in 73% yield after 1 h. HMF and LA can also be obtained selectively with 100% yield from fructose at 140 °C after 1 h, in DMSO or 1,4-dioxane, respectively. EL, HMF, LA and EMF were also produced in moderate to good yields from other carbohydrates such as inulin and sucrose. The catalyst HReO4 can be used in gram scale for the production of EL, EMF, HMF and LA with good yields and in at least 8 catalytic cycles on the conversion of fructose into EL with no significant reduction in its activity.
coredata.dc:title: HReO4 as highly efficient and selective catalyst for the conversion of carbohydrates into value added chemicals
